Beginner's Guide
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Farm Online Games (Computer): Monster Farm: Online (the original ranching game, no longer available): FAQ (basic essentials, read this first!): Beginner's Guide
By NorseFTX on Saturday, May 24, 2008 - 10:31 am:

This guide is to help you get started, and to give you a few basics about the game.
This doesn't cover how to set up the game installation and VPN, however! If you need help with that, the "About Log-in Troubles..." thread is the place to look.
A great deal of this info is thanks to the Monster Farm Online (MFO) wiki!

TABLE OF CONTENTS

1) Getting Started - Creating a Monster
  i) Types of regeneration
  ii) Monster types available at start
2) Orienting yourself
  i) The Map (key 'L'), Important Locations

3) Your Monster

  iv) Aging

===========================================

1) Getting Started - Creating a Monster
The moment you finish creating your character and enter the world, you will appear in the middle of what seems to be an empty field surrounded by some fence. A person will be standing in front of you, and introducing you to the world of Monster Farm Online--this place you start at is your Farm!
It might look bare now, but you'll be able to purchase upgrades later on as you earn more money.

Once you finish clicking through their dialogue, you can head out of the fence and to the Shrine, the mid-right exit lined in white.

It's time to receive your first monster!

i) Types of regeneration
When you enter the shrine, there will be four options on the screen with two available (the last one is to leave).

    -"Regeneration"
    -"Item regeneration"
    -"Transmigration"
    -"Fusion"
    -[Exit Shrine]

"Regeneration" is normal regeneration either using an in-game Stone Slate, or using a CD/DVD.
"Item regeneration" may be the creation of a monster with the assistance of an item;
"Transmigration" is transferring the crystal of an old monster that you have raised into a new monster (which doesn't have to be the same species). Some fraction of stats can be retained. To create a monster crystal, some quests will have to be completed.
"Fusion" is the fusion of your monster with another player's monster. This feature may not have been implemented, as there are no records of people having used it yet.

Right now, you will only be able to do the first, as you do not have any items or monsters yet.
When you select the first option, press the left option ('Yes'), and it will give you three options:

--CD/DVD Regeneration-- | --Stone Disk Regeneration-- | --Cancel--

In this game, CD/DVDs will not give individual monsters!
You will choose the breed of your monster yourself; the only thing that CD/DVDs will effect is the stats of the monster, their personality traits, and possibly if they are a special breed.
You also start with one Disk, but if you've got CDs, I suggest using those. The stats on your CDs/DVDs would likely be better than the default Disk stats that you start with.

(The Disk you start with, as far as I know, will always be an Antelo)

ii) Monster types available at start
-Antelo: A Monster that learns Lightning/Ice techniques, relatively well balanced overall.
-Korunu: A Monster that learns Ice/Earth techniques; built to have high physical power.
-Tiger: A Monster that learns Lightning/Ice techniques; a good physical attacker with quick movement.
-Kikimo: A Monster that learns Fire techniques; a long-range combat specialist.
-Pixie: A Monster that learns Fire/Lightning techniques, and has high intelligence.
-Hare: A Monster that learns Wind/Earth techniques, and has great skill and speed.

----------------------------------------------

2) Orienting Yourself
Right after you create your monster, you will be taken back to your farm. You should head to town now, which is the mid-left exit (with the brown gate). Choose any of the channels that you'd like to enter.

You'll be taken to the town chief, who will offer to give you a tutorial. ("Yes" will be the left choice, "No" will be the choice on the right--this is always how the Yes/No menus will be placed).
Taking the tutorial is a great way to get used to the battle controls if this is your first time.

In the Tutorial, you will be pitted against a giant doll that looks like an enormous Mew. It's motionless and doesn't attack, but has massive amounts of HP (compared to how much damage your monster does), but if you've got patience, you can actually kill it and it may drop an item.

Once you're done, you can head out of the tutorial area.
You will come back to the town, where the Town Chief will talk to you a little bit more, and then will ask you whether you want a Potion (you can say "Yes", left choice, to receive a free one) and he will also give you a piece of Food. You can begin exploring now!

i) The Map (key 'L'), Important Locations
You will start in the "Town Hub" of sorts.
You can see the map by pressing the 'L' button on the keyboard.


ii) Vendors and NPCs
Several Vendors and NPCs are available, and here is a quick list of known Vendors/NPCs.
(See Map for locations)

There are two currencies:
SP - Normal money
MP - Money that can only be purchased with a credit card/etc from their site at http://www.mf-online.jp/ .

-Food Vendor: Sells various types of food for your monster. (Food sold is initially only Rank 1/2 Food)
-Medicine Vendor: Sells potions (HP restoring, Status recovery, etc)
-Farm Object Vendor: Sells things that can be placed on the farm.
-Clothing Vendor: Sells clothing and accessories for the breeder.
-Monster Accessory Vendor: Sells clothing and accessories for your monster.
-Quest Vendor: Where you accept and turn in quests.

iii) The Quest System
Quests are how you increase your breeder rank.
BP (Breeder Points) will be received when you complete a quest for the first time, along with some SP.

You can repeat quests as many times as you want, but you will only get SP from then on. (BP can only be gained from completing new quests).

The Quest Vendor has 3 options when you click on them:
-New Quest
-Turn in Quests
-Cancel

When new Quests are accepted, you will be able to keep track of them in the Quest menu (the 6th option on the menu to the left, or press the 'O' key).

----------------------------------------------

3) Your Monster
Now we'll talk about your monster!
The small portrait on your top left contains your Breeder name, the picture of your monster, the Name, Level, and Life bar.

i) Status Screen (key 'M')
When you press 'M', it will bring up the Monster's status screen.
I'll explain each of the entries:
Name
Species
Level
Grade
Age (Year/Month/Week)
Height
Weight
Body Type		Condition
Hunger Meter
Life
POW
INT
SKI
SPD
DEF
SPR
ACC		Characteristics


POW - Higher POW will increase the damage done by Physical Attacks
INT - Higher INT increases damage done by Magical (Int-type) attacks
SKI - SKI will increase the hit rate of your monster's techniques; it also increases chance of inflicting status effects for skills that do inflict status effects.
SPD - Increases the rate that your monster dodges attacks; also increases their movement speed during battle.
DEF - Decreases the amount of damage taken from Physical Attacks.
SPR - Decreases amount of damage taken from Magical (Int-type) attacks, and also affects the types and frequency of changes of your monster's moods.
ACC - Increases the chance of a critical hit, and may also affect the execution speed of techniques.

ii) Raising Stats
The way a monster's stats increase is by feeding them food; when your monster is hungry, you can feed them for a better effect than when they are almost full.

After its stats increase a certain amount, your monster will Level Up, and you will gain some life and will be able to learn some new techniques.

There are also 8 Food Types available, each of which affect certain things:

Meat - Increases POW the most
Fish/Shellfish - Increases INT the most
Vegetables - Increases SKI the most
Fruit - Increases SPD the most
Grain - Increases DEF the most
Mushrooms - Increases SPR the most
Milk - Increases ACC the most
Honey - Will fill monster's hunger fully, and will also affect all stats.

Certain foods will tend to change the Color of your monster, too:
Red: Salmon, Carrot, Mushroom, certain Meats
Blue: Crab Meat, White Turnip
Green: Green Fruits, Vegetables
Yellow: Fruit, Grain
Purple: Purple Vegetables and Fruits, and some meats

Each of the food types also falls into sub-categories of nutrients, which determine how they will affect your monster's weight:

NutrientFood TypesEffects
ProteinMeat, GrainBody will grow.
LipidMeatWill cause monster to become fat.
VitaminsFish, VegetablesWill help maintain body weight.
MineralsMushroomsEnhances growth of Monster Horns.
SugarsFruits, Honey Will make monster happy, but is fattening and stunts growth.


iii) Techniques
There are four total 'ranges' available to techniques:

Short - usuable in the red range of distance
Medium - usable in the yellow range of distance
Long - usable in the blue range of distance
Extreme - usable outside the blue range (when the circle around your enemy is white)

Techniques can be learned as your monster continues to battle and level up (you must be at a certain level to learn some techniques).

If you'd like to set one of your techniques to a shortcut, you must first be in Town or at the Farm, and open the Skill menu (key 'K'), and drag the skill to a box in the lower right that matches its range.

iv) Aging
Your monster will age as they get hungry, so in a way, your hunger meter bar (right above the Life bar on the monster status screen, key 'M') is the same as your monster's aging measure.

Monsters get hungry from 3 main things:
1) Using Techniques
2) Getting damage from enemies
3) In-game time passes (about 0.1% of the hunger meter depletes every minute)

Lifespans and Life patterns vary for different monsters, but not much is known about them yet.
